column4: And with roaming mode enabled, nm-applet shows me connected, but if I ping my router, it says network is unreachable. I'd really like to get this fixed and not have to constantly fight with it.
Ok, this time, I just checked the routing table, and there is an entry. The destination is 169.254.0.0. Should it be the 192.168.1.1 address of my router?
that depends on the address given to your interface
I'm a little clueless on how to figure it all out. :D I know just a little to get by, but have no clue once I run into a problem.
at a terminal.  type   ifconfig eth0  # if eth0 is the interface that is connected to the router
at the second or third line in the output - you should see the IP address given to that interface
It's ath0, and there is no IP address anywhere, just the rx/tx packet information, which is all 0
so it seems like your interface hasn't got an IP address - which explains the odd route in the routing table.
I got back "No DHCPOFFERS received" and "No working leases in persistent database"
Could it be the router in that case?
it could be - but it could also be the drivers for your interface (have they ever worked?)
Yeah, it worked perfectly for a week, until I disabled roaming mode.
errm, i think you need to enable roaming mode
i'm not sure - i don't use gnome too much - but i believe roaming mode is what sets the interface in a state to recieve IP addressess automatically
That's where I'm at now, and nm-applet shows it connected. But I still have no internet access and can't ping the router.
Well, when you enter the connection manually, you can set it to dhcp.
yea, kinda the same problem i had with the atheros chipset on my NC10 - i had to use the madwifi drivers to get wireless to work properly
